{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3548273,"name":"PhilBot","username":"PhilBot","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/philbot/{size}/1824_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T15:53:54.182Z","cooked":"

Note: I’m running version 25.0.4 on my SPARK Flexs and REV Lib.

The setup: Our robot has two CAN busses.
The CTRE drive train is using a CANavore, and the Elevator is using the vannila RoboRio CAN bus with 5 SPARK Flex motors.

The Problem: A couple of Flex motors on the Elevator consistantly drop into a mode where they report “Timed out while waiting for Periodic Status 0” every 1-2 seconds.

This seems to start happening when the robot is just sitting there disabled for 5+ minutes, or when there is a transition from active to disabled.

Once the motor gets into this state, the only way to clear it is to either cycle the power, or do a Restart RoboRio. A simple code restart or reload is NOT sufficient to clear the fault.

While the error is being reported, if I connect the REV Hardware client, there are NO errors or sticky faults showing up on any of the motors.

The motor that does this the most is actually the MASTER in a set of three Flex motors where the other two are set to follow the Master. When the error starts occuring, the motor triplet just go into a stutter mode where the Elevator jerks up an inch and then sits there for the rest of the 1-2 seconds and then jerks up again. So it’s REALLY a problem.

This may also occur on one of the other motors, but it does not seem to effect it as much, and does not appear to stop it from moving correctlty.

The other similarity between these two motors are that they are both running in closed loop position mode. One with an external absolute encoder, and one with it’s internal relative encoder.

Any suggestions as to what is hapenning and what I can do to test or remediate this problem. Our event is in 2 days.

I can’t help you much, but here is a link to another spark problem. Although I don’t know how well it will work.

Best of luck.

Also, I’d drop a link to your code so people smarter than me can check it out.

Questions:

  • What is your can bus utilization in driver station? What values does it hover around?
  • Are you configuring motor status frames in any way? How?

The main culprit I’d first assign blame to is CAN bus wiring. Check that thoroughly for anything loose or broken.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T16:16:37.339Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":57,"readers_count":56,"score":21.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":494346,"topic_slug":"spark-flex-motors-get-locked-in-timed-out-while-waiting-for-periodic-status-0","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":55016,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/spark-flex-motors-get-locked-in-timed-out-while-waiting-for-periodic-status-0/494346/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3548674,"name":"sticky_1629","username":"sticky_1629","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sticky_1629/{size}/10017_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T21:36:52.815Z","cooked":"

Utilization is only 20%.

We are not messing with motor frames in any way.

CAN wiring “should” be solid, but what’s weird is that this fault does not usually occur when we are driving around. It mostly happens when the robot is just sitting there, enabled or disabled . Then once it happens it locks in.

So, after many hours of debugging, and working with REV, the problem has been tied to an interaction between the FLEX firmware and the PlayingWithFusion TOF sensor.

Could you please elaborate on this solution? I think we are seeing similar issues with two of our SparkFlex controllers (our pivot arm leader and follower) - that after being on a while (and sitting still) one or both of them will just decide to start reporting timing out until we reflash them. We have the PlayingWithFusion ToF, but this seemed to happen with or without the ToF in the loop.
